The plastic end caps on our curtain blinds cracked with age and fell off.
I made my own replacements in the color I wanted.
Just check the dimensions of the rod (in the openscad) matches what you need or scale it to suit. The default rod diameter is 17.8mm.

This was specifically designed to fit my iPhone which is in a case and my tripod quick release head (which is a Manfroto 3265 pistol grip head).  Throw in the Bluetooth remote control, the XLR microphone adapter, a boom and lavaliere microphone and a small audio mixing board and you have a fairly respectable video camera setup.  
Keep an eye out for the more generic version coming soon.  I'll add the files to this post.  I'll change the design to hold an iPhone 6 with no case and will modify the base so it can be mounted using a standard tripod mount. Stay Tuned!

These were printed using ABS so I used clear ABS cement available at any hardware store in the ABS/PVC pipe section.  Obviously there are a million other glues or straight acetone or MEK will work as well.  You'll have to figure out what to use with your particular media and print job.

remixed_from.author: LostTime
remixed_from.title: Turn your ammunition box into a storage box

description.text: This is a very simple but useful stress spreading washer designed for M3 Nuts and Bolts.  The printed washer spreads the stress from the nut and machine screw, reducing the tendency to crack acrylic and other brittle plastics.  It also reduce the tendency of the hardware to dig in and crush wood panel.  Also the plastic improves the friction of the nut to hold it still while tightening the machine screw.

Print this solid  or pretty much solid.  Play with parameters in the Open SCAD file,  to adjust the fit, diameter, thickness, etc.  You can also change the number of washers in the array, so that with a single print you  can have as many as you need.  It also adds a simple wipe object in the corner to prevent crap on the edge of the first washer in the array.  These print fast, and are very useful.  Print a bunch to have handy.

title: Customizable whiteboard eraser and marker holder with name

description.text: The erase holder clips onto the bottom of the whiteboard and has space for an eraser and holes for 4 markers. The front edge has space for text which I use via writescad.

The width is set to 200mm!
It prints support pins for the 4 'clip' triangles that can be easily removed with a screwdriver or knife once complete to leave a flat bottom edge.
The name can be set at the top of the openscad file or can be completely ignored by commenting out line 36.
NB: My writescad is in the libraries/Writescad subdirectory below the model. The "`" apostrophe character I used is the only one in the font that produces a single tick!

This is a Derivative of the original Yazzo PolyBot by WilliamAAdams. I found the original design to be something I wanted to build and test with immediately. So I found some things I wanted to do differently and wanted other people to experiment with this awesome robot. UPDATE: The Female and Male Clevis Elbows I had uploaded here are the wrong size. I no longer have the proper size on my computer. Please follow these links to get them: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8130
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8129 On the original Polybot the files were spread around Thingiverse and were very hard to find, I have consolidated them into one spot. I have also changed the threaded rod connectors of the Tetrahedron support structure. These new ones should be much easier to print and will print without support. They should also be much sturdier. I have also changed the servo brackets to make them much easier to mount the servos. You no longer have to take apart your servos and struggle with getting them back together in order to mount them. The servos also sit out further off the platform. With the original design, the servos sat too far in on the platform making it impossible to get a good range of motion for the servo arms. One of the negatives of these new designs is the need for fasteners. The original PolyBot was designed to use as few fasteners as possible. This one can be edited to make the holes smaller on the printed parts for the threaded rod to fit snugly into without the use of nuts. I prefer to use nuts because it makes assembly so much easier. Nuts are pretty inexpensive too and you are probably going to be in the hardware store anyway for the threaded rod. Currently, I am using standard Medium Hobby Servos to move the arms. For now they work really well and easily move the lightweight arms of this bot. As for the micro-controller, I am using a Picaxe 28X/40X. But you can use whatever you like. If you find this bot to be interesting, I seriously recommend printing and building it. It is pretty cheap to build and doesn't take much time. It is a lot of fun to mess around with. As for improvements, I already have a bunch of ideas in mind. And I know WilliamAAdams is working on improvements for the original Cranberry Yazzo Polybot, hopefully he will release something soon! Here is a video of it moving... I should have gotten it to do something more interesting. But I have to go to work in the morning and I spent the night preparing the files and doing this write-up. Kind of lame, more and better video soon! I promise! http://www.flickr.com/photos/[email protected]/5587175033/ Another update... I couldn't leave it for the night with just that crappy first video. So I programmed some numbers that might make the bot look like it is moving semi-coherently. So here is a better video of Delta Robot Movement: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fWZOHDWu0EM

Print out the following: 12 Clevis Elbows - Male - Follow the Download link in the description!
12 Clevis Elbows - Female - Follow the Download link in the description!
1 Tritool Effector
3 Keyed Swivel Mounts
3 Servo Horn Arms
3 Servo Brackets
3 Tetrahedron Base pieces
1 Tetrahedron Top Piece
3 Tetrahedron Middle Pieces Note: This design was meant to use 8mm threaded rod. I used 5/16 inch rod because it is difficult for me to get metric threaded rod. The design is such that either 8mm or 5/16th inch rod will both work great. Build the Tetrahedron (three sided pyramid), I used precut 2' long 5/16 threaded rod that I bought from Home Depot. I purchased 6 2' pieces and one 3 foot piece. You can use whatever size you want, the design is scalable. Of course the limitation would be the diameter of the rod, you probably won't want to make the segments TOO long, because it will be unstable. You will also need around 42 5/16" nuts. The Tetrahedron Connectors are designed so the rod goes through the connector and pokes out the other side a little further than the width of a nut. A nut is supposed to be placed on each side of the connector for each rod piece that intersects with a connector (look at the pictures if that isn't clear). Don't forget the middle connectors will need nuts of their own threaded on. The length of the edges of the triangle that makes up the middle platform (where the servos sit) is 9 inches. This is an equilateral triangle too, so that means the middle platform sits 9 inches down from the top of the tetrahedron. Just cut the 3' foot pieces so you get 3 x 9" pieces. Next you can put a piece of plywood or something on the middle platform. I used foam core. This piece doesn't need to be super sturdy in the bots current state. I have been running it fine with foam core. The piece of foam core I used is secured to the threaded rod with zip ties. Next you can build the actual moving part of the robot. I used 5/16" wooden dowels around 7 inches long. You will need 6 of them. Connect the female clevis elbows to the ends of both sides of each dowel. Then you can attach the male clevis elbows with some 3mm nuts and bolts to the female clevis elbows (Sorry I can't stick to one unit of measurement, hardware stores in the USA don't carry Metric threaded rod). Now you are going to need some short 5/16" dowels to link the male elbows to each other and the keyed swivel mount and servo horn linkage. You can now attach the tri-tool to the keyed swivel mount. Don't attach the servo horn arm to the servos yet. Now just mount your servos to your servo brackets. With this new servo bracket design, you will need to bolt them in too. I used more 3mm nuts and bolts to do this. Trust me, its alot easier they taking the servo apart and trying to jam it through the old servo mount. A lot can go wrong when you do that. I then secured my servo mounts to the platform using zip ties through the closed off rectangle of the servo bracket. I only used one zip tie on each and they seem to hold fine for now. You probably want to hook up your micro-controller before you attach your servo arms to the servos. That way you can make sure they are all at the right positions (or you could manually move the servo to the maximum or minimum of the range with your hands). Now once you have the angle right attach the servo arms. And now you should have a Delta Robot Test Platform!

title: How small a line can your printer produce?

description.text:
I wanted to find the smallest line my printer could produce so I made this print produce every combination from .1x.1 to 1x1 in a 10cm x 10cm grid.
The y values increment along 1 side while the z values increment on the other.
Fidn the smallest one that you're happy with and then count the squares (in both directions) from the .1x.1 to determine it's size.

The test lines are printed on top of a .6 wide by .2 high grid which is 10cm x 10cm.
The test line is drawn diagonally across each 10mm x 10mm square.
The height increases by .1mm along the x-axis and the width increases by .1mm along the y-axis.
The square finishing at 10,10mm will be .1mm high and .1mm wide.
The square finishing at 40,60mm will be .4mm high and .6mm wide.

author: net_id

description.text:
This is a 250 size Mini-Tricopter called the Switch Blade based on it's folding arm design. This is ideally sized for 2204 size brushless motors, with 12A ESC's and 3S LiPo battery power. Please check back as I update the instruction pages with a list of required parts. Check out my build thread on Flite Test:
http://forum.flitetest.com/showthread.php?16432-mpbiv-s-3D-Printed-Folding-Tricopter-a-work-in-progress

Required Hardware Items:
===================== (10X) M2.2 Self tapping screw, 6mm long (used to secure printed frame pieces together)
http://www.mcmaster.com/#96817a865/=wowf75 (4X) M2.2 Self tapping screw, 4mm long (used to secure 32x32mm FPV camera)
http://www.mcmaster.com/#96817a861/=wowf6v (8X) M3 Self tapping screw, 8mm long (used to mount flight 36x36mm flight controller and printed tail boom)
http://www.mcmaster.com/#96817a908/=wowgq3 (8X) M3 Socket head cap screw, 16mm long (used to mount front motor mounting)
http://www.mcmaster.com/#93070a073/=wowh7y (2X) M3 Socket head cap screw, 5mm long (used for tail motor mounting)
http://www.mcmaster.com/#91239a110/=wowhjx (3X) Anti-vibration Bobbins (used to isolate the camera tray assembly)
http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__40615__Vibration_Damping_Balls_150g_61_Blue_8_PCS_.html (4X) Flanged ABEC-7 Ball Bearings (used for front arm pivots, will eventually be replaced with printed bushings)
http://www.mcmaster.com/#4262t15/=wowj1m (1X) 1/8" Clevis Pin (used as tail pivot axle)
http://www.mcmaster.com/#92390a075/=wowllc (2X) Carbon tube .375" OD, .25" ID, cut to 4.2" Length (used for front booms)
http://www.rockwestcomposites.com/products/45546 (1X) Hitec HS-45HB Servo (current yaw mechanism only fits this servo, but I plan to update the design later)
https://www.servocity.com/html/hs-45hb_premium_feather.html#.VSfa9a10xUQ Suggested Electronics:
==================== (1X) Flight Controller: Naze32, Tau Labs Sparky, BrainFPV, or anything with 36x36mm PCB (30.5x30.5mm mounting) (3X) 2204-size Brushless Motors: Cobra 2300kv or 1960kv, Sunnysky 2300kv, anything with a 16x19mm bolt spacing will work with mounts (3X) 12A ESC's: SimonK or BLHeli, or KISS suggested, I used 12A ZTW Spiders for my build, and Lumenier 12A ESC's are also a good option. (1X) FPV Board Camera: SONY 600TVL is what I used but most 32x32mm size cameras should work (1X) 5.8 GHz Video Transmitter: TS5823 32ch 200mW, the upper plate is specifically designed for this transmitter to snap in, but others can be used. (1X) 5.8 GHz Antenna: I used a circular polarized with a right angle connector directly on the video transmitter above. (3X) Props: HQ 6045's are good, frame will fit any 6" or smaller prop (Multiple) Battery: 1300mAh 3S LiPo, 45C or higher discharge recommended Assembly Notes:
===============
  • The clevis pin in the hardware list above is used as the tail pivot. The pin should move freely in the motor mount portion of the yaw mechanism and have a slight interference/press fit in the pivot tab on the tail boom. If the pin moves freely in both parts, use a dab of epoxy near the head of the pin to prevent it from falling out during flight.
  • Printed yaw motor mount has integrated spline which matches Hitec HS-45HB servo. Use the screw that comes with the servo to attach these two parts.

description.text: Quickly change 50mm filament spools using this amazing free spinning spool holder. The holder rotates freely to reduce friction and ensure smooth prints. Convenient slots enable you to quickly secure the spool using a filament clip. As a bonus, you don't lose filament clips. Both 1.75mm and 3.0mm filament clips are part of this project. Works with existing DeltaMaker spool mount. Video of the spool holder in operation: https://youtu.be/kO6lQuzWjT8 This spool holder requires a bolt and lock nut commonly available at most hardware stores. The cost is usually less than 40 cents.

Requirements: 5/16" x 3.5" hex head bolt, 5/16" lock nut, 1/2" socket, and printed parts
  • Print parts without support or raft
  • Snap off supports from the Spool Holder Mount
  • Insert bolt in the back of the Spool Holder Mount until flush
  • Slide the Spool Holder onto Spool Holder Mount bolt
  • If the Spool Holder doesn't rotate freely run the bolt in and out to wear down imperfections. You can also try 300-600 grit sandpaper on the smooth section of the bolt.
  • Attach the lock nut to the bolt with a 1/2" socket.
  • Tighten the lock nut so that the Spool Holder still spins freely.
  • Attach new Spool Holder to back of DeltaMaker and enjoy!
    • Spool Holder Mount - Infill 100%
    Spool Holder - Infill 25%
    Filament Clip - Infill 15%

description.text:
This is a replacement for the outside cover of the blower scroll fan that is used to cool the plastic after it leaves the hot end.
The nozzle that was supplied with the printer was simply an insert to the fan and it had to be kept in place with sticky tape (see pictures).
This piece replaces the clipped on a screwed in outside cover from the fan.
The pictures show the before and after.

Print it.
Unscrew the 2 screws on the fan,
Pry the top cover off from the outlet - you'll need to release the 3 clips as it starts to come apart.
Using the screw and clips to align the new nozzle, replace the screws and clip it into place.
Enjoy!

author: net_id

title: Hinge for the Front Door of the Lulzbot Enclosure

description.text:
Nice simple hinge for the acrylic door of my Lulzbot Mini enclosure. Uses two M3 machine screws on a 30mm x 18mm centers. Hinge uses Stress relieving washers (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:755320) on the back side to provide a forgiving mount to the 3mm Acrylic door and frame. Hinge is designed to used either a Long M3 machine screw or a short length of 3mm filament as the hinge pin.
I've updated this thing, to make the hinge a little more robust (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:772303) if you're interested or If you are interested in an entire add-on kit to enclose your Lulzbot Mini, Ive put together a kit that includes these hinges and lasercut acrylic panels. You can check it out at: http://drazzticaction.com/products-page-2/3dprinters/ or http://www.ebay.com/itm/Add-on-Enclosure-for-Lulzbot-Mini-3D-Printer-/291446076488?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_0&hash=item43db8a3448

Printed with 10 percent fill, as the stress on this part should be low.  Depending on how clean the print comes off the printer, you may need to clean it up a little with a file or razor blade to have a smooth functioning hinge.

comments.text: Was looking for a sturdy flush hinge to mount the door on my enclosure. These are perfect. Tight fit and really strong. Thanks!

author: Khrood

description.text:
Inspired by the legendary Aztec civilization, this bracelet honors the God of light, justice, mercy and wind: Quetzalcoatl. As his name indicates,  “the feathered serpent”, Quetzalcoatl embodied the union between earth and sky. One of the most fascinating Aztec myths says that Quetzalcoatl was born from Coatlicue, who already had 400 children who transformed themselves into the stars of the Milky Way.  
Inspirados en la legendaria civilización Azteca, este brazalete es un homenaje al dios de la luz, la justicia, la compasión y el viento: Quetzalcoatl. Como lo indica su nombre, “serpiente emplumada”, Quetzalcoatl simboliza la unión entre la tierra y el cielo. Uno de los mitos Aztecas más fascinantes cuenta que la madre de Quetzalcoatl, Coatlicue, dio a luz a 400 dioses que se convirtieron en las estrellas que conforman la Vía Láctea.

Broke my cross bar and tried epoxy and some other things before making a quick fix on the printer, worked like a charm!
have crashed it plenty more and haven't been able to break it again. its a little tight inside, used flat top 20mm m3 screws and lock nuts on the top, 5mm piece on top, 3mm piece on bottom. using two 3mm pieces would work fine tho. will probably end up replacing the cross bar anyways since my break was pretty bad, but when i do i'll slim the design down a bit and put it in to prevent it from happening again. .. Ended up dropping it out of the sky from about the same distance that broke it the first time and broke one of the legs off completely. turned the whole center hub into a abs glue patty, let dry for 2-3 days and fly's, but still should replace it. will make a better support b4 install when i can get another one.

This is a two part rotating latch for use on a 3mm thick acrylic door. Along with the Hinges (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:755437) and the Stress relieving washers (www.thingiverse.com/thing:755320), these printed parts make the Complete door assembly for the Lulzbot Mini Enclosure. The enclosure minimizes the cracking and warping of parts and provides a secure enclosure to keep dust and rodents and rugrats out of your printer. Added a slighly larger version of the latch, less critical on the printing dimensions.

This latch was printed at 10% fill and a single shell. Depending on the quality of the print, it may require a little touching up to mate.  Bolts together with an M3 machine screw.  Latch requires a 8mm hole in the 3mm acrylic door, 4.5mm from the edge of the door.  Latch handle base acts a stop for the door, and the handle rotates to lock.  The mating pin and slot are eight sided, so the handle can be aligned at various angles relative to the latch arm.  Works very smooth.  An optional detent hole in the door fram can be used to create a more secure locking action.  
Version 2 is larger and less critically dependent on the printer tolerances.

author: patrick_lee

title: E-3D Mount - Creator Bot 3D by - 3D Printer Works

description.text:
UPDATE 28APR2015: Main/First Hot End Installed and Working - http://3dprinterworks.boards.net/post/1456 UPDATE: Modified the the carriage to make it stronger and better fit. Added Slave carriage for dual simultaneous printing (Work In Progress). If you have a single head printer or 1-E3D Jtype hot end, you can use just this mount and be up and printing. Added: Fan Duct for 30mm 12v Fan
Added: Teaser Photo of the Slave Design for printing two identical objects at once on the same print bed. Hardware you will need... Clamp the two halves together.
2x 3x45mm
2x 3mm lock nut Secure the Belt - NOTE: You should attach the right end of the belt X-Axis belt prior to assembling the two halves. Do not over tighten the set screws.
2x 2x12mm Mount the Cable Chain Guide
2x 3x16mm
2x 3x10mm Fan Duct
2x 3x12mm Pan or Button
4x 3x 12mm (Attach Fan) Slave Carriage (still In Development/Testing)
?in x 12mm diameter carbon fiber rod
? Springs
? Screws
y-harness to slave extruder motors Print The carriage top down - With supports (Ben's default setting in SLIC3R worked fine. Turn the print temp on the ABS down to 238 and leave the bed temp at 110 for the duration of the print. Let the bed completely cool and your part will pop right off. No glue or tape on the glass required. Print the cable chain holder upright - No supports required, 20 infill, ABS or PLA, the bottom of the chain will rest on the top of the support and you will run the provided plastic bolt from top all the way through to the bottom. Note: There are two holes on the front of the carriage for the planned part's cooling duct to mount. The uploaded files are slightly different than the pictures. This is a work in progress.

Hot End Assembly - wiki.e3d-online.com/wiki/E3D-v6_Assembly
Note: Use thermal grease on the barrel threads into the cooling fans. Provides better heat distribution and prevents jamming due to improper cooling. Carriage Parts to print - www.thingiverse.com/thing:755560
NOTE: I've only completed the single hot end configureation at this time. The description in Thingiverse lists all the hardware that you will need. Modify Slice Settings: SPEED IS YOUR FRIEND Retraction: 2mm
Print Speeds: Be careful to no go below 40mm/s Print head like to jam at slow speeds
DON'T leave the filament in the hot end when print is finished - I'm using these to help prevent jam in restart ///////USE AT OWN RISK/////// START G-Code G28 ; home all axes
G1 Z10 F5000 ; lift nozzle
G92 E0 ; zero the extruded length
G1 E105 F225 ; load/purge nozzle with 5mm of filament
G92 E0 ; zero the extruded length END G-CODE M140 S0 ; shut off bed
G1 E-100 ; retract filament by 100mm
M104 S0 ; turn off temperature
G1 X225 Y225 ; X and Y axis Back Right Corner
M84 ; disable motors ///////USE AT OWN RISK/////// Print in ABS 30%infill with supports. (I printed at 245): The Two main carriage halfs.
The Parts duct if desired.
The E-Chain Rest. The holes that use 3mm hardware will need drilled out for easier assembly. It's best to mount the half with the motion belts first, then assemble the rest once you have the tension set. The belt channel may require some slight trimming if you don't get a perfectly smooth print. Electrical
You can reuse the heater from the Creator bot.
Use the E-3D Thermistor (Don't forget to modify Merlin)
Remove the extra creator bot heater and Thermistor. Important:
Run Auto Tune M303 once the installation is complete and update your PID in the config.h This is what I ran - M303S190C10 (Tuning for 190 degrees for PLA)
Then write down you new P.I.D. - update it in the firmware and reflash your Ramps 1.4 board. My New PID was:
P: 32.40
I: 3.80
D: 69.01 In the firmware you will need to reduce the max Z-height by 4in (100mm) and X offset to 10mm. You will also need to fabricate a Z-end stop screw extension or get a longer screw. For my 12x12x12 printer, My max Z = 205mm (about 8 in) This is of no concern to me since I don't print anything over 4-6in tall. Load it all up and run a test print.

This is a very rough Mixed Oxidant Generator. Check out http://www.appropedia.org/Printable_Mixed_Oxidant_Generator for more details. It is used to make oxidants which can be used to sterilize water. I have uploaded 2 SolidEdge files and one .stl file to get you going. The first has one manometer, the second seperate ones for the oxygen and hydrogen that will be evolved. The manometers are not sensitive enough (I think). Please feel free to experiment. There is a lot of work to be done, but for a very worthy cause!

These are very rough instructions, and won't produce a working Mixed Oxidant Generator. It is a good base for experimentation, but that's it. Please work on it! These exist commercially, I am sure that we can find a way to make a simple, affordable generator to sterilize water using a catalyst, some salt, and a current source like a solar panel.
  • Print on something like a RepRap. Use maximum infill to prevent porosity, which could cause leakage and loss of suction.
  • This is a one piece print. Just set it and forget it.
  • Cut electrodes out of tin plate to fit into the electrode slot. They can be heated to seal them.
  • Pour a saturated brine solution into the holding tank.
  • Apply a current across the electrodes. The suitability of the tinplate as an electro catalyst, the amount of current to apply, and the ability to measure the level of oxygen and hydrogen evolved with a high enough resolution are the main issues. Please explore these issues!.

title: Proxxon Mount Plate for Prusa i3 mini CNC Router

description.text:
If you like what you see consider using my referral link on Banggood. Thanks!
12% off on FPV Stuff: https://goo.gl/39KJyG.
 Turn your Prusa i3 into a mini CNC Router! This mount is a drop in replacement for a printing extruder. Fits X-Carriage from the i3 Rework set. Mount is rigid enough for milling light materials and works great on plywood. I haven't done testing on other materials though. You might need to attach your prusa frame to a ground plate to make it more stable (Mendel90 fixing blocks work great for wooden frames!). This mount fits Proxxon FBS 240. It should fit Proxxon IBS too.
Please report any issues and post images of your milled work! Customised Marlin Fork for milling: https://github.com/Ognog/SandCrab Looking for new gadgets? Click here: https://goo.gl/k3dc3d Check out my other things too: http://www.thingiverse.com/samella/designs

description.text:
This is a custom build of an wifi speaker made out of the following materials:
  • Harman Kardon HK S4 Speaker
  • Raspberry Pi B+ with RuneAudio
  • Adafruit Mono 2.5W Class D Audio Amplifier - PAM8302
  • Optional: Custom board (Stereo to Mono)
  • EDIMAX EW-7811UN Wireless USB Adapter
    • I solder everything directly to the Raspberry Pi B+ board, but if you want to reuse the board some time you could use adapters or an breakout board. But keep in mind that you don't have so much space. I have modified the existing Raspberry Pi B+ case, because I missed ventilator slots and want to directly mount my Speaker to it.
Print with support and make sure that you use an high resolution that the speaker fits.

author: Kaworru

description.text: I know that it seems a crazy printer but I've printed the mechanical parts and now it seems not so crazy. The printer uses an arm to manage the extruder (not yet fully tested). The advantages are the large flexibility of area printable and the very low cost of parts. I've used less than 500g of filament, 4 smooth rods, 4 linear bearing and 8 circular bearing (less than 20Euro). I've attached here also the firmware based on Marlin. WARNING: it is a very preliminary version and it must be completed. Currently XYZ movements are partially tested. I'll keep you informed about its progress. http://youtu.be/L5frg2ia4BM

Software: OpenScad, Cura
Printer: Prusa I3
Filament: PLA 3mm
Extruder: 0.4mm
Layer: 0.2mm
Fill: 30%
Support material: yes (pattern 15%)
Brim: no
Temperatures: 195° extruder, 60° hot bed
Fixing method: adhesive tape

comments.text: A RUMBA board would do everything 5 Thermositers 3 Heated beds and 2 heated heads Up to 6 Motors 6 Endstop switches  , it is about $135.00US @ marginallyclever .com vs.$185.00USfor RAMPS boards just a thought , no thermal inertia worries and maybe even one of the hotends gets to be a hotbed.  As it is arduino compatible little if any difference in code. (that would keep the workload lighter) And as it is used for palletizing arms, maybe it would help with your printer.
comments.author: 0nl1ne0nt1m3

comments.text:
So this looks like a fascinating printer , have you maintained extruder pressure / retraction with a guide tube ?
My true curiosity would be in heating all 3 hotbeds , I have a couple of Arduino RAMPS boards .
Do you think with separate power sources 2 of the 3 could be heated with the second board?
One of the RAMPs is a dual extruder with up to 5 motor signals and if pushed, heating both a hotbed , J Head ,6 motors (Mendel Z Axis) end stops and 3 fans from one board. but the other 2 beds and maybe some fans could be powered by a second board with a "virtual sketch" telling it to keep the beds heated to the right temperature ? Just some food for thought.
comments.author: 0nl1ne0nt1m3

comments.text:
Yes, I will use a PTFE tube for the filament, but I haven't yet tested. Currently I have published the version of the top part with vertical filament management instead horizontal to reduce the friction and torsion with tube during arm movement.
For the hotbeds you can use more power sources, but my idea is to use a single power supply with a single Arduino board then switching the power supply (and thermistors) between three beds using relais controlled from Arduino taking advantage from the thermal inertia of the hotbed. The Marlin firmware should be upgraded to do this. Long job ...

comments.author: Lyscanthrope

comments.text: I'm using Arduino Marlin firmware. I've modified the SCARA parts of code to manage only one arm (SCARA uses two arms joined together and the mathematics is little bit different). In the version published here the gear ratio is 50/13 and it should guarantee 0.3mm of resolution on the head, but now I'm reengineering the arms for use gears with ratio 55/10 that should guarantee 0.15mm of resolution. Another test that I'm doing is to use ABS plastic instead PLA. This because ABS is less rigid than PLA and it could reduce the oscillation of head ... this weekend I'll publish my improvements and new videos.

As many guys I started with a Mendel90. My printer was bulit according nophead github files with some changes due to parts availability. If you print PLA all is fine but when starting with ABS or other stuff a very small smell of a wind can destroy your print. I looked on thingiverse and in several online resources but nothing was appropriate to cover the Dibond version without having an extra housing. The design was done in 123D Design. My printer frame is from 3mm aluminium sheets but there is no difference in general. As I am not using any 300mm spool I changed the spool and filament parts on the back also to get a fine rear covering: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:744868 The cover plates are made from corrugated cardbox material. Of course, you can use Dibond, Acrylic, Polycarbonate or something similar with 3mm thickness but cardbox is the cheapest. The moveable top cover should be cutted from 4mm material to ensure less bending. FreeRider did from his make an assembly vid: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cBtCV-YE-bg . Enjoy. UPDATE 2017-10: Added the 123Design file and STEP file. Not the best but sufficient for further development. I do not know when or if I will continue with the details. UPDATE 2017-03: Just adding the last changes within this month. UPDATE 2015-04-07: Vertical stand has been printed but for the other parts I am struggling with bad filament causing print failures after some hours of printing. New material already ordered.
  • Main picture updated to latest version
  • Latch grip modified (longer, thicker) ->V1.1
  • Locking pin added
  • fixing block added
  • cover plates and drill scheme added

total print time 46h,5h and 447g ABS

STILL UNDER PROGRESS COME BACK LATER One guy who made this enclosure put all parts of the front housing on one plate. I used several colors and split the prints into small and long parts. Therefore print time etc will vary. Sliced with Cura. I have not tested with Skinforge or Slic3er but it will be probably not faster;) Accuracy is quite ok for this project. Plastic parts

description.text: A name tag for your cup! Fits on most German coffee mugs.

The STL is only here for visualization. You can print it, if you want, but then your coffee mug is all mine! ;-)
  • Download the OpenSCAD script (kaffeetassen.scad) and put it into a folder on your hard drive.
  • Get Write.scad and orbitron.dxf from Thing 16193.
  • Drop Write.scad and orbitron.dxf into a new subfolder named write/ relative to kaffeetassen.scad.
  • Open kaffeetassen.scad in OpenSCAD, and change the name in line 12.
    • Don't put more than 10 characters, or it will cap the text.
    • Or, change the font size by changing the parameter h in the writecylinder call to something smaller (line 75).
  • Render the model in OpenSCAD (press F6)
  • Go get a coffee (or a faster CPU).
  • Export the model to your favourite 3D file format and throw it onto your 3D production line.
  • If the clip is too hard to put on your handle or to remove, tune the inner ends of the clip with a rasp.

author: ben1234

title: X-Wing Miniatures game Pilot & Damage Card Boxes

description.text: These card boxes are designed for the X-Wing miniatures game cards. There are two sizes, the Pilot card box and the smaller box for the Damage/Upgrade cards. Also included are the faction logos to print out and glue to the circular bit on the lid of the pilot boxes (if you want to do that). I've also created boxes for many of the ships in a similar style here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:707019 I'd love to see how yours come out so please post pictures! UPDATE: By request, I have added a larger version of this box, the STL files are marked TOPLOADER and they are to fit the 3x4inch toploader card sleeves. EXTRA! I've created a booklet of additional X-Wing missions in the style of the ones you get with the Core Set and expansions. There's missions for all three factions, including some 3-sided ones. You can download them from here: http://www.other-worlds.co.uk/new-x-wing-missions/ - Enjoy!

Print as placed, they should fit on any type of printer since they are pretty small.For one large box you'll need to print one base and one lid. The smaller box is placed with the lid and box in one file. I use the following to print:
1.75mm PLA, .15 layer height, 0 perimeters, no supports/raft/brim should be necessary.

  • The Logos on the Lid:
    These are printed separately. Just glue them on afterwards (or not!)

  • The Hinge:
    You'll need a bit of 1.75mm filament for the hinge pin, I hold a lighter to the sticking-out-end of the filament once it's inserted into the hinge for about 1-2 seconds, then use a wet finger to push the hot end a little (be careful!) that'll be enough to make the filament bulge out and stop it sliding around (do this to both ends).

  • Finishing:
    The clip at the front is quite tight when first printed, it needs a bit of sanding/filing down (just a few seconds) to get it to a place that you're happy with. I like it to really grip the box so it's very hard to flip open, but you can just sand it down a little more to tune it to your needs.

  • Painting:
    Whatever you like! I used Acrylics airbrushed on for the box and the blaster-burns on the rebel boxes, and brush-painted the weathered red on the rebel logos. Then drybrushed with silver. The imperial boxes are just airbrushed a flat gunmetal type grey.

comments.text: The pilot card box seems like its way too big. Even with sleeves on its almost 1cm too big. I scaled it to 86% in my slicer and that was perfect for unsleeved cards. The holes for the hinge still fit 1.75mm filament through them easily. Upgrade box seems to be the right size though.

author: engineer119

description.text: Here's a customizable candle holder that can be used for Shabbat candles. I had the campers at the URJ 6 Points Sci-Tech Academy http://scitech.urjcamps.org in mind when I designed this. There are a number of parameters that can be used to significantly vary this design. Click on the "Open in Customizer" button and adjust the sliders. But be careful as there are some combinations that are unprintable. Also some will require supports while others, such as the one in the photos, will not. Most Shabbat candle holder pairs are identical but there's no rule that says they need to be. Try and make the designs similar but not identical so they relate to each other in some way that may not be obvious. If you want to try other parameter settings that aren't possible with the Customizer, the OpenSCAD source is included so you may edit that directly.

Designed in OpenSCAD, sliced in Simplify3D, printed on a MakerBot Replicator2 with Elmer's Craft Bond glue stick on a glass build plate with PushPlastic filament and the following settings: Infill = 20%
Layer height = 0.2
No. shells = 4
Feedrate = 40
Travel Feed = 55
Temperature = 220C Support may be needed depending on the design. Typically if the under-hangs are 45 degrees or steeper, then won't need support.

title: Plate for Nine Men's Morris (in french: jeu du moulin)

description.text:
Il s'agit du jeu du moulin. Amis francophones je vous laisse voir sur wikipedia http://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeu_du_moulin Thanks Wikipedia http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nine_Men%27s_Morris for the rules: The board consists of a grid with twenty-four intersections or points. Each player has nine pieces, or "men", usually coloured black and white. Players try to form 'mills'— three of their own men lined horizontally or vertically—allowing a player to remove an opponent's man from the game. A player wins by reducing the opponent to two pieces (where he could no longer form mills and thus be unable to win), or by leaving him without a legal move. The game proceeds in three phases:
  • Placing men on vacant points
  • Moving men to adjacent points
  • optional phase) Moving men to any vacant point when a player has been reduced to three men

Nine Men's Morris starts on an empty board.  
The game begins with an empty board. The players determine who plays first, then take turns placing their men one per play on empty points. If a player is able to place three of his pieces in a straight line, vertically or horizontally, he has formed a mill and may remove one of his opponent's pieces from the board and the game. Any piece can be chosen for the removal, but a piece not in an opponent's mill must be selected, if possible.

Players continue to alternate moves, this time moving a man to an adjacent point. A piece may not "jump" another piece. Players continue to try to form mills and remove their opponent's pieces in the same manner as in phase one. A player may "break" a mill by moving one of his pieces out of an existing mill, then moving the piece back to form the same mill a second time (or any number of times), each time removing one of his opponent's men. The act of removing an opponent's man is sometimes called "pounding" the opponent. When one player has been reduced to three men, phase three begins.

When a player is reduced to three pieces, there is no longer a limitation of moving to only adjacent points: The player's men may "fly", "hop",[3][4] or "jump"[5] from any point to any vacant point.  
Some rules sources say this is the way the game is played,[4][5] some treat it as a variation,[3][6][7][8] and some don't mention it at all.[9] A 19th-century games manual calls this the "truly rustic mode of playing the game".[3] Flying was introduced to compensate when the weaker side is one man away from losing the game.

Print, as you want, plateau.stl or plateau2.stl (faster) . Size is 180 X 180 mm Print the checkers in one color
Print the chekers again using another color

title: Foldable Swiss Army Style Key Holder

description.text:
I have tried other Swiss Army style key holders / key rings on Thingiverse, and found that they all suffered from the same problem: it was difficult for me to actually get at the keys, and near impossible to do it with one hand.  
My solution was to design one that folded in the middle to allow for easy access to the keys. Fold it one way to expose one set of keys, fold it the other way to expose the other set. You can even do it one-handed, which you will appreciate if the other hand is holding groceries.

The key holder consists of four identical parts. Print them with no support and a good amount of infill. Please see the side-view photo for the proper orientation. Use 3mm screws and nuts to hold it all together – button heads preferably. You may have to trim or grind the excess length of the screws after assembly. Make sure to pad out one side with washers if you have a different number of keys from one side to the next.

This is a quick and (very) simple Python script to read data from an ASCII format PGM (portable gray map) file and convert it to a "surface" data file for OpenSCAD.  
You will need Python (written for v2.7), and numpy to run it, but it's quick to convert. You will need OpenSCAD to utilize the output of this script.

Unlike a certain other "lithopane" thing, this is not limited to a small image size. However, you must be able to convert your original photo to a PGM file. You can do that quite easily with either IrfanView or with ImageMagick. I'm sure there are a dozen (at least) other tools that can do this too, but you need to make sure the PGM file is ASCII formatted (not binary) and that is has no (0) compression. Steps:
1) Edit your digital image, then convert to PGM. 2) Run this script with Python 2.7 like this:
python pgm2surf.py myImage.pgm myImageSurf.dat 3) In OpenSCAD, use the "surface" command to import the DAT file, like this:
surface(file = "c:/myCoolStuff/myImageSurf.dat", center = false, convexity = 10); Notes:
1) The surface is flipped both top to bottom and left to right when you create the surface in OpenSCAD. You can plan accordingly by editing your image in the photo editor before creating the PGM file. 2) There is a "depth" value in this script that reduces the heights of the surface values. I've set it to 0.03 after several trials, but you might want to play with that value, depending on your purpose for the surface. A value of 0.5 yields a surface that has a very high relief from the highest point to the lowest. It might be good if you want to create a mold of the image.
The depth value can be set as the last argument on the command line when calling the script, like this:
python pgm2surf.py myImage.pgm myImageSurf.dat 0.5 3) For a "cookie cutter" type mold, you want to "invert" your photo (create the negative) before creating the PGM file. Try it and see. 4) My apologies to Linux users, the typical python directive is missing from the top of the script. Please add it if you need it. (BTW, the image example shown above is from a photo taken just after my parents' wedding, 50 years ago. They celebrated their 50th anniversary last week. Happy Anniversary! Now immortalized on the Internet.) UPDATE:
While trying to get OpenSCAD to generate an STL file from the surface data, I found that it crashes... more often than not. The problem seems to be the number of vertices in the generated surface. I've been successful in generating an STL from a surface as large as 162 x 200 (pixels in the PGM file) but anything large crashes OpenSCAD. YMMV. (Yes, that means the example image I showed is very unrealistic... oops!)

comments.author: applefreak

comments.text: I think the easiest way to add a smooth frame around a surface would be to edit the image before you generated the PGM file. Add a gray border around the image in your photo editor. The darker the gray tone, the higher the frame will be. If you want a thin (light) frame, make it lighter gray. If you added some white circles in the border then you'd have a starting point for drilling mounting holes too. If that doesn't help, then you'll need to learn to use the difference() function in OpenSCAD.

comments.text:
My apologies on the (glacially) slow reply. I think the PGM file might not be in the format recognized by the Python code. That's about the best guess I have without knowing more about your input file and how it was created.
Some programs that generate PGM files will add comments in the beginning of the file, and they might not be handled well. It's no stretch to say that this code would not exit gracefully in that situation.

description.text:
Saw these for the first time in Thailand a couple years ago but they cost $30 for even the simplest. Now you can print your own! Three STLs uploaded are 5cm tall, 10cm tall, and 15cm tall giving you your baby, mama, and papa lamp shades. Yeah, have fun printing 30 of those 15cm pieces! First one to do so gets a pat on the back. Scale the parts to your liking for different sizes and piece thickness. I also added DXF files for diversity UPDATE:
My favorite results so far for the 30 piece sphere have been with a 125 mm size printed with two .25mm layers and 4 perimeters, so I've uploaded this one as well.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Stoof's MendelMax 1.5++

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25mm

Infill:

100%

Notes: Print with 2 layers at 100% infill and 4 perimeters

Choose a design from the instruction booklet in the gallery also found here:
http://bit.ly/11hMEON
Or get creative and figure out your own... Print the required number in any color or combination of colors you like, print, and then have fun figuring out how to put them together. You might break a few the first few tries. I would suggest only printing with ABS because the only thing you would get out of printing these with PLA is frustration and disappointment (parts have to be pretty flexible). But go ahead, prove me wrong. The thickness of the STLs are 0.6mm, but they can easily be scaled to your liking using netfabb or similar. I printed 3 layers at 0.2mm, but please feel free to play around with different thicknesses and layer combinations and tell me what you like best! After you've put together all but the last few pieces of it, stick it on a hanging lantern cord or whatever you like, add the final pieces, and hang it up! (Hint: try different combinations of plastic colors and light bulb colors. Red shade with green bulb??? Trippy maaaan) Heres a video of somebody putting it together
http://bit.ly/19S2At9

I wanted my printer to switch off automatically after printer job done
and not caring about fans still running. So I decided to create this thing. The Power of my printer is derived from an ATX Power adapter and the Printer On switch basically shortcuts the green wire of the ATX supply to ground. When my printer jobs finishes, my printer does a homing of X and Y, so wenn X axis reaches home position, this could tigger a limit switch.(switch off) So the basic Idea is to create a second "switched" On switch.
This is an electrical path from ground to 2nd onSwitch - to extra limit switch - and finally to to green wire. So when you successfully started your print job, you would supply the printer from the 2nd on switch. Actually a simple limit switch is not sufficient: When homing triggers the limit switch it will disconnect the power, but when looses force it might snap back , providing power again to the printer. So the printer will just make a reset, but not switch off. You need something like a latch. This is what I realized here. A Video showing the functionality
of the switch is at http://youtu.be/8Bw0QOTs684. Here you see my installed auto-power-off :
http://youtu.be/IdwWwwvrUUY

You need
  • the plastic print
  • a 5mm diameter 10mm small spring
  • a small skrew to fix the spring
  • A limit switch with 10mm Hole distance
  • 2 M2x8 skrews top
    • Print with 0.15mm layer height, no support
    use a file and 5.5mm drill to finetune the result.
    Attach the spring to the latch, insert the latch into the case.
    mount the spring with the skrew, then insert the locker and
    finally mount the limit switch.

description.text:
These paperweights show two different hemispheres of the moon; one the side visible from earth; the other the hidden side. A bottom is provided which can be glued on after filling with weights. Two hundred post 1982 zinc pennies, which weight about half a kilogram, can be contained in each paper weight.

My SmartrapCore from SmartFriendz is really cool, but the cables inside the box are kind of messy and, since I installed the Bowden extrudeur inside the box, and the filament is coming from the roll that is just outside the box, there's a friction between the filament and the box border.
I designed this small and simple piece to resolve both problems : it holds the cables on the right side inside the box, and works as a guide for the filament, to keep it at a not-too-bad angle, and away from any friction with the wooden box.
The hole that guides the filament is curved just enough, and the inside diameter and widening in and out openings let the filament slide really smoothly.
The cables can be put in the holding part by gently bending the piece, and I made holes to screw it to the wooden box (10mm thick), but mine holds just fine without any screw.
And yes, there's a little bunny on the front. I put bunnies on my designs now, just for fun. :) Update (07/30/2015) : I added a smaller version that only helps the filament to slide around the box border (no cables holding if you don't need that).

title: Treble Clef - An example of using the snake line approach...

description.text: When I extended my sline module (the OpenScad module I used for generating the spring integrated in my flexible battery holder) to allow for skewed "snake lines", I was looking for a simple example to illustrate and test my module. That's when I thought of the treble clef (aka "violin key") as being a perfect example of such a snake line... I liked what came out of my little exercise. As may be someone else might be interested in it as well, I thought, why not publish it here on thingiverse... ? For those interested in the implementation, have look at the SCAD file. If you just want to print the clef, two STL files are provided: one for printing in normal position and one for printing the clef upside down (to get a flat and shiny top level for the finished object). Update 2014-04-05: I have now also uploaded two smaller versions with lengths 100mm and 65mm (the full length version being 185mm long).

I printed this object from 3mm ABS on my DIY box-frame Prusa i3, using a 0.40mm nozzle with 0.25mm layer height and 0.56mm extrusion width.   
I always print on a clear mirror without Kapton tape, but thoroughly cleaned with acetone and double concentrated lemon juice

Ventilation Grill // Lüftungsgitter See how it workes:
https://youtu.be/_rwp_XEQvB4 I made this for one of my frinds bathroom.

Re-designed the whole clip, I did print the original one but was a bit too thick.
Sony Belt Clip A.stl
Sony Belt Clip B.stl The new design is closer to the original and has a clip. The clip's hole is for 1.75mm filament that you can use, the only thing extra you need is a small spring to get the clip to have tension. I used an old hair clip from my wife and took the spring, then used it for my new walkman clip. No supports needed or rafts. I do not have the screw for it but made the screw hole, this helps it clip to the walkman nicely. I believe this fits other walkman models, but cant test as I only have this, but while Googling i found that the following walkman might work.
Sony WM-F15
Sony WM-F65 Let me know if it fits any other. Cheers

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.02

Infill:

10% and above

You need an extra spring I got the spring from an old hair clip. Place it in the between the holder and clip, insert a 1.75mm filament and melt the ends a little to keep it in place. Add a small screw (Sorry don't know the size) to secure the holder. Enjoy your walkman on your belt.

author: FDMTech

title: Removeable Spool Holder Arm and Bracket for Lulzbot Mini

description.text: This is a modification of the standard spool arm on the Lulzbot Mini. It replaces the hinge with a simple U Bracket, using the same mounting holes on the frame. The advantages are two-fold. First the hinged arm caused no end of trouble when moving the printer. It flops down at the worst possible times, and when in the folded position, it doesn't really sit inside the profile of the case, so it is easy to snag on things. But, most importantly, because the hinged mechanism crosses the plane of the case opening, it prevents us from easily putting an enclosure panel on that side. This modification simply removes the hinged portion from the bottom of the arm, and replaces the hinge on the frame with a U-bracket which securely holds the arm, and allows for it to be easily removed for transport. Finally, the new profile on the right side of the machine allows us to easily add an enclosure panel onto the printer. If you are interested in an entire add-on kit to enclose your Lulzbot Mini, Ive put together a kit that includes this thing and lasercut acrylic panels. You can check it out at: http://drazzticaction.com/products-page-2/3dprinters/ or http://www.ebay.com/itm/Add-on-Enclosure-for-Lulzbot-Mini-3D-Printer-/291446076488?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_0&hash=item43db8a3448

The OpenSCAD file for the arm simply cuts the bottom of the existing Arm (spool_mount_v1.2_Mini.STL) and rounds the end.  This modification could also be done too the existing arm that ships with the machine, with a bandsaw, and a file (that is what I've done).  Simply cut off the bottom inch of the arm and taper it smoothly to insert into the printed bracket.  You will also need four 30mm long M3 machine screws to attach this to the side of your printer.  You can use the existing mounting bracket that comes with the printer, and simply  reverse it, so that the hinge slots are to the inside, as they won't be used.  That is it, slide the arm into the bracket and voila! you  have a nice secure, low profile, removable filament spool arm.

title: An E3D Chimera Bracket for Ooznest Prusa i3

description.text: UPDATE: This design has been updated to include layer fans so that you can print with PLA. See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:857270 for the update. I got an email Friday saying they finally shipped my Chimera hot-end so I thought I had better get my finger out and make a bracket to fit on my ooznest prusa i3. Inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:661185, this one has cable-tie holes on either side of the bracket and two "tails" to give a bit of air flow round the back. So I came up with Chimera-high. I also moved the mounting holes on the x-carriage up (x-car-high). Then I had another read of the docs, and the four grub screws should be accessible. Well, they were kinda, if you take the fan of first... But it would be easier from the back, even if I lose a bit of print height... So Chimera-std was born and I went back to the standard x-carriage. Today I saw http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:643799 and I liked so I adapted the x-carriage to have the same belt grip and the chimera-ext and x-car ext came into being. All mods were done in Blender and I have included the blends for all three variants. I'm going with Chimera-ext though it is a work in progress, but not for long - I got the Chimera this afternoon.

I use Cura, my settings are:
Layer Height: 0.2
Shell Thickness: .8
Top/Bottom thickness: 0.60
Fill Density: 25%
Print speed: 55mm/s No supports

title: Airsoft Stock locking tab/button for A&K; Masada

description.text:
A quick part I designed to replace the broken one on my Airsoft A&K masada.
The sides are slightly oversized to compensate for shrinkage when printing in ABS, you may have to shrink them (or file them down) if you print in PLA or nylon.
No shaving or fililng should be required if you print at 95% scale, it should drop right in and work like a charm.

Print in layers of .3mm or less, at an infill of 60% or greater, for best results print at a scale of .95 (95%)
Set the support material option to "everywhere" with the threshhold of 20 (so it'll support overhangs), you will have a lot of support material underneath, but it should be easy to remove with a pair of needlenose pliers and gives a good looking final print.
Recommended material is Nylon for durability, but it will work in ABS or PLA.
My test piece was printed in Hatchbox black ABS at 230C with the bed heated to 110C on a Kossel mini at a layer height of .2mm and 100% infill.

title: Improved y-axis endstop (Mech Endstop) side mount for Prusa i3

description.text:
A better Y axis endstop side mount for all ready-rod style Prusa i3 Printers.  
Mounts to 10mm threaded bars. Uses all mounting holes for Mech Endstop v1.2 (M3) and includes blanks for the solder, pins, and electrical connection to ensure a tight and durable fit. Design is automatically Y-axis adjustable so the entire print bed can be used.  
Endstop mounts to a bracket using short M3 screws w/nuts and 2.8mm diameter electrical connector standouts (optional - requires printing w/supports). Bracket mounts to the threaded rod and is held to the frame using frame and nuts. Endpoint trigger is the bed frame (near center) allowing for max Y printing distance.  
v2: Cables can exit next to the y-axis motor keeping the underside of the frame nice and clean. Added rounded corners and three versions (by request) for x-small, small, and medium distances (threaded rod to bed frame).  
SketchUp (source) files included.

Simply measure the distance from the top of your threaded rod to the top of the bed frame (the size will be different based on the bearings used and bed to smooth rod mount type used). Based on the (mm) distance, choose either x-small, small, or medium mount to print. Supports are required for required to correctly print the 2.8mm holes (those located next to the electrical connector). If you don't care about these being supported print a "nosupport" version. X-Small = 41mm (LMU88 bearings w/8mm smooth rods)
Small = 44mm (LMU10 bearings w/8mm smooth rods)
Medium = 45mm (LMU10 bearings w/10mm smooth rods)

title: Latches for the Acrylic Panels Lulzbot Mini Enclosure

description.text:
These little clips hold acrylic panels as part of a simple secure easily removable enclosure system for 3D printers. These were used for enclosures for the Lulzbot Mini and a variant for the Makerbot Replicator. These are designed to be cut from 5mm acrylic, but they could be cut from anything up to 1/4", or 3D printed There is an improved printable version of this clip at: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1044852 We recommend you use this printable version, when printing these clips. The slots on the mating panels would need to be adjusted accordingly, to accommodate different thicknesses. I would not go thinner than 5mm, as they need some heft to distribute the forces on the panel and avoid cracking it, and to provide a secure installation. The lower clips (long ones) are designed to slide up on the panels for installation, and to be held in the locked position by gravity. As such these clips only work well in a vertical orientation.
Use with Lulzbot Mini Acrylic panel profiles: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:994992 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:756211 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:756173 If you're interested in a kit of all the laser cut panels and printed parts to enclose your Lulzbot Mini, we have an enclosure kit available at: http://drazzticaction.com/products-page-2/3dprinters/lulzbot-acrylic-enclosure/ Enjoy,
Jim Rasmussen
TabSynth Design Works LLC
Laser cut from 5mm or larger Acrylic.  They could also be 3D printed.  Included is an OpenSCAD file to extrude the profile to 5mm thickness, for printing.  The STL file is the output.

This tricopter heck motor mount fits on a 12mm carbon tube. It has mounting holes for common 1804 motors.

Took apart those cheap chinese wireless charging dock and kept the qi module, you can also buy it for less than $10 on dx http://www.dx.com/s/qi+module the two semi circles indicates the center of the coil, Solidworks file is uploaded so you can change it yourself. Made it for my nexus 5 but it will work on any phone with any module, just take measurements.
turned out pretty nice.

comments.text: How do you get the Qi module inside of this? I'm a bit confused on that, thanks!
comments.author: CorneliousJD

comments.text:
if you take a section view from the right plane, you will see two internal slot in V configuration, they intersect near the bottom.
you will insert the coil and the pcb separately(de-solder it duhhh)
insert the coil from bottom into the slot 1 (closer to the front of dock), feed the wires in as well but into slot 2(leads towards the back) now you will see the wires from coil hanging off the back(if too short then just add a jumper cable to increase the length) solder the wires back to the board before inserting the board into slot 2.

title: Travel case for RIF6 Cube Video Projector

description.text: This is a simple travel case for the RIF6 Video Projector - a marvellous 2 inch cube projector that can project a 120in picture. The bump at the front indicates where the lens will end up. There is a cutout for the focus wheel, to avoid damaging it. There is a cutout for the power button, to avoid the projector being turned on accidentally. Finally, there are two cutouts for ventilation, so you can use the case as a stand if you want to project onto the ceiling. To keep the projector in the case, use friction (e.g. a small felt pad stuck inside).
